text.tspan: creates apps in his spare time

flowRoot.flowPara: Mikko is building an application that gives suggestions what clothes to wear. It needs to know the weather forecast and he wonders how he can get that data.

Mikko googles "weather forecast data" and finds some information. Then he googles "weather api" and finds more options. Finally he googles "best weather api" and finds a blogpost by apinf.io (programmableweb.com)
Mikko wants to build something useful.
It's a side project so how can Mikko be as efficient as possible?
Limited amount of time, no budget
Blogpost of apinf's publication on medium.com
Mikko finds many options and wants to know which one to pick.
How can you find out which API to trust?
Surprised by the amount of choice
The blogpost leads Mikko to the category "weather" of APIs on apinf.io, ranked by score (popularity). He can see all the weather APIs and gets the basic information about each in the catalog.

Mikko clicks on the most popular weather API and reads the first page with more info. He finds other information on that page too, such as projects using the API, code examples, blog posts, changelog,...
He finds the option to try out the API by clicking a button. He plays around a bit with different requests and responses.
He likes that he can play with it immediatly.
Mikko still goes back to the catalog and quickly browses #2 and 3 of the APIs, but decides to give the first API a try in his app, since it seemed to do the job.

When Mikko made a choice to use a certain API, there are clear instructions how to proceed. He is briefly interupted to sign-up, but he reads that an account is required to obtain an API key. He also reads that this key can be used for any API on apinf.io and likes it that he can manage all APIs he might use in the future in one place.
After signup, Mikko receives his API key. With the help of code examples and incorporating the generated SDK, he manages to make a first test call from within his application within 30 minutes.
